Knowledge Point: The default and unmarked mood in statements is indicative, when something is stated as a fact. If the speaker wants to strengthen the proposition more, the intensity adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{akena} `truly, very' is added to the end of the statement \REF{ex:6:x1050}, \REF{ex:6:x1051}.
Content 1: \gll Wi owow oko oko pun wia maake-miaw-i-yem \textbf{akena}. | \gls 3p.UNM place other other also 3p.ACC tell-wander-NPS-PR.1s truly | \glt  `I really walk around telling people in many other places too.'
Content 2: \gll Wi o ook-owa nain me pepek \textbf{akena}. | \gls 3p.UNM 3s.UNM follow.him-NMZ that1 not able truly | \glt  `They really are not able to follow him.'

Knowledge Point: When the proposition is considered less than certain, either probable or just possible, the modal adverb clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{yon} `probably/perhaps/I think' (\sectref{sec:3.9.3}) is attached to the last word in the statement, usually either a verb \REF{ex:6:x1052} or non-verbal predicate \REF{ex:6:x1053}. An interjection can still follow the word with -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{yon} \REF{ex:6:x1071}.
Content 1: \gll Mua Maneka=ke lawisiw wia amukar-e-k=\textbf{yon}. | \gls man big=CF somewhat 3p.ACC scold-PA-3s-perhaps | \glt  `Perhaps God reproached/punished them a little.'
Content 2: \gll Nis pun kema puk-owa marewa=ke=\textbf{yon} aa! | \gls 2p.UNM also liver burst-NMZ none=CF-perhaps INTJ | \glt  `Ah, I think you don't have any sense at all (lit: your liver hasn't burst)!'
Content 3: \gll Naap=\textbf{yon}. | \gls thus-perhaps | \glt  `I think/suppose it is like that.'

Knowledge Point: The counterfactual form of the verb (\sectref{sec:3.8.3.2}) is used in speculative statements where the situation mentioned in the proposition \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{did not}} happen, although it could have \REF{ex:6:x1054}--\REF{ex:6:x1056}.
Content 1: \gll Lawisiw akena um-\textbf{ek}-a-m. | \gls somewhat very die-CNTF-PA-1s | \glt  `I very nearly fell (but in reality didn't).'
Content 2: \gll Naap wiar amis-ar-\textbf{ek}-a-mik oo! | \gls thus 3.DAT knowledge-INCH-CNTF-PA-1/3p INTJ | \glt  `Oh, if only we had known that about him/them!'

Knowledge Point: Abilitative is expressed by the adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pepek} `enough, correctly, able' as a non-verbal predicate. In affirmative statements the verb that the adverb refers to often occurs in the following clause \REF{ex:6:x1089}:
Content 1: \gll No \textbf{pepek}, eliw on-i-nan. | \gls 2s.UNM able well do-Np-FU.2s | \glt  `You are able, you can do it.'

Knowledge Point: The verb may also be in the same clause but in the nominalized form; this is more common in negative statements \REF{ex:6:x1088}:
Content 1: \gll {\dots} mukuna nain \textbf{umuk-owa} \textbf{me} \textbf{pepek}. | \gls ... fire that1 extinguish-NMZ not able | \glt  `{\dots} (we were) not able to extinguish the fire.'

Knowledge Point: The syntactic strategy for expressing strong obligation is to use the nominalized form of the verb followed by the contrastive focus clitic, and optionally an appropriate form of the verb `be' \REF{ex:6:x1077}.
Content 1: \gll Yo uurika owow maneka \textbf{ikiw-owa=ke} \textbf{(ik-ua)}. | \gls 1s.UNM tomorrow village big go-NMZ=CF be-PA.3s | \glt  `I have to go to town tomorrow.'

Knowledge Point: A nominalized clause structure may may be interpreted to express obligation even without the contrastive focus clitic, and in a medial clause. A dative pronoun is added if clarification is needed to state who is obligated to do something \REF{ex:6:x1079}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ekap-owa} \textbf{efar} \textbf{ika-eya} ekap-e-m. | \gls come-NMZ 1s.DAT be-2/3s.DS come-PA-1s | \glt  `I had to come, so I came.'

Knowledge Point: A polite request can also take the form of a question \REF{ex:6:x1163}.
Content 1: \gll No maa nain=ko eliw yi-i-nan=i? | \gls 2s.UNM thing that=NF well give.me-Np-FU.2s=QM | \glt  `Will/would you give that to me (please)?'

Knowledge Point: Permission is indicated by the adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{eliw} `well/all right' placed before the verb, which is in the future form \REF{ex:6:x1085}, \REF{ex:6:x1086}.
Content 1: \gll Yiena miiwa kuisow, \textbf{eliw} feeke soop-i-yen. | \gls 1p.GEN land one well here.CF bury-Np-FU.1p | \glt  `Our land is one, we may bury him here.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Eliw} ek-ap fook-i-nan, fook-ap ep-i-nan. | \gls well come-SS.SEQ split-Np-FU.2s split-SS.SEQ go-Np-FU.2s | \glt  `You may come and split (coconuts), and having split them, go.'

Knowledge Point: Prohibition or denial of permission is done with a negated nominalized form of a verb \REF{ex:6:x1087}, \REF{ex:6:x1078}.
Content 1: \gll Manin maneka na-isow nena kookal-owa=pa \textbf{perek-owa} \textbf{weetak.} | \gls garden big 2s.ISOL 2s.GEN like-NMZ=LOC harvest-NMZ no | \glt  `You are not allowed to harvest the big garden by yourself when your like.'
Content 2: \gll I \textbf{me} sira samora \textbf{on-owa=ke}, weetak. | \gls 1p.UNM not custom bad do-NMZ=CF no | \glt  `We must not do bad things.'

Knowledge Point: In sentences expressing disobedience to a prohibition, it is particularly common to have the prohibition in a relative clause where the nominalized verb is negated with the verbal negator \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} \REF{ex:6:x1887}, \REF{ex:6:x1888}. Here the contrastive focus clitic is not used.
Content 1: \gll Maa=ko \textbf{me} \textbf{on-owa} nain nis=ke on-i-man. | \gls thing=NF not do-NMZ that1 2p.FC=CF do-Np-PR.2p | \glt  `You do things that must not be done.'
Content 2: \gll Sabat fofa=pa \textbf{me} \textbf{uuw-owa} nain emeria nain saliw-a-k. | \gls sabbath day=LOC not work-NMZ that1 woman that1 heal-PA-3s | \glt  `He healed the woman on a Sabbath day when it was forbidden to work.'

Knowledge Point: Verbal clauses are negated with the negator \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} `not', placed before the verb \REF{ex:6:x1090}, verbal group \REF{ex:6:x1091} or verb phrase \REF{ex:6:x1092}.
Content 1: \gll I iinan aasa \textbf{me} \textbf{kuuf-a-mik}. | \gls 1p.UNM sky canoe not see-PA-1/3p | \glt  `We did not see the airplanes.'
Content 2: \gll Yo \textbf{me} \textbf{keker} \textbf{op-a-m}, Kedem=ke makena. | \gls 1s.UNM not fear hold-PA-1s, Kedem=CF true | \glt  `I was not afraid, true, Kedem was.'
Content 3: \gll Mua \textbf{me} \textbf{wia} \textbf{kuuf-a-mik}, \textbf{me} \textbf{wia} \textbf{furew-a-mik}, ne \textbf{me} \textbf{wia} \textbf{imen-a-mik}. | \gls man not 3p.ACC see-PA-1/3p not 3p.ACC sense-PA-1/3p and not 3p.ACC find-PA-1/3p | \glt  `We did not see, sense, or find the men.'

Knowledge Point: This type of negation, also called standard negation, is symmetric in Mauwake: the negative clause is similar to the corresponding affirmative clause apart from the presence of the negator \citep[61--67]{Miestamo2005}. The negation strategy is the same for transitive and intransitive, independent and dependent clauses, and for imperatives \REF{ex:6:x1113} as well.
Content 1: \gll Ni \textbf{uf-ep=na} maadara \textbf{me} \textbf{iirar-eka}. | \gls 2p.UNM dance-SS.SEQ=NF forehead.ornament not remove-IMP.2p | \glt  `If/when you have danced, do not remove your forehead ornaments.'

Knowledge Point: The non-verbal predicate in equative \REF{ex:6:x1093} and descriptive clauses \REF{ex:6:x1095} can be negated with any of the four negators.
Content 1: \gll O somek mua \textbf{weetak/wia}. | \gls 3s.UNM song man no | \glt  `He is not a teacher.'
Content 2: \gll O \textbf{me} somek mua=ke. | \gls 3s.UNM not song man=CF | \glt  `He is not a teacher.'

Knowledge Point: However, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{marew} is possible in these clauses only if the predicate contains an adjective \REF{ex:6:x1096}.
Content 1: \gll Awuliak fain afila \textbf{weetak/wia/marew}. | \gls sweet.potato this sweet no | \glt  `This sweet potato is not sweet.'

Knowledge Point: When the possessive and existential clauses are negated with the verbal negator \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me}, they are like other verbal clauses \REF{ex:6:x1098}, \REF{ex:6:x1099}. But if any of the other negators is used, the negator replaces the verb and becomes a non-verbal predicate, so these clauses become verbless clauses \REF{ex:6:x1094}, \REF{ex:6:x1100} (\sectref{sec:5.6.3}).
Content 1: \gll I sira naap \textbf{me} \textbf{yiar} \textbf{ik-ua}. | \gls 1p.UNM custom thus not 1p.DAT be-PA.3s | \glt  `We do not have a custom like that.'
Content 2: \gll Iiriw miiwa muuta nain irak-owa \textbf{me} \textbf{ik-ua.} | \gls earlier land for that1 fight-NMZ not be-PA.3s | \glt  `Earlier there was no fighting for land.'
Content 3: \gll Wi Yaapan emeria \textbf{weetak}, mua manek=iw. | \gls 3p.UNM Japan woman no, man big=LIM | \glt  `The Japanese had no women/wives, (they were) only men.'

Knowledge Point: With so many possible alternatives, the speaker has a choice of repeating the same negator \REF{ex:6:x1128} or using different ones \REF{ex:6:x1127} when several items are negated. Either strategy is used by good language users.
Content 1: \gll I muuka \textbf{marew} a, i wiipa \textbf{marew} a. | \gls 1p.UNM son no(ne) oh 1p.UNM daughter no(ne) oh | \glt  `We have no son, and we have no daughter.'
Content 2: \gll I urupa \textbf{weetak}, i soomia \textbf{wia}, i epira \textbf{marew.} | \gls 1p.UNM cup no 1p.UNM spoon no 1p.UNM plate no(ne) | \glt  `We had no cups, we had no spoons, we had no plates.'

Knowledge Point: In a few cases the choice of a negator indicates a difference in meaning. The example \REF{ex:6:x1130} is the Mauwake equivalent for the common Tok Pisin idiom \textstyleForeignWords{nogat tok } `I do not have anything against it'.
Content 1: \gll Yo opora \textbf{marew}. | \gls 1p.UNM talk no(ne) | \glt  `I have no talk. (= It is OK / I do not have anything against it.)'

Knowledge Point: The predicate function of the negators \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{weetak} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{marew} is also shown in the fact that they take a medial different-subject suffix, when the verbless negative possessive or existential-presentative clauses occur sentence-medially in a chaining structure \REF{ex:6:x1101}. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Wia} cannot be suffixed with the medial verb suffix.
Content 1: \gll Maa pela \textbf{marew-eya} / \textbf{weetak-eya} fofa er-a-m. | \gls thing leaf no(ne)-2/3s.DS / no-2/3s.DS market go-PA-1s | \glt  `I had no greens and went to the market.'

Knowledge Point: Papuan languages typically do not have lexicalized constituent negation of the type `nothing', `nobody' etc., and even syntactic constituent negation may be lacking \citep[271--272]{Reesink1987}. But in Mauwake it is possible to negate various constituents within a clause, and, although very rarely, even inside a noun phrase. The basic constituent negator is \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} `not'. It precedes the negated element, which receives extra stress. Position of the negator, stress, and sometimes the neutral focus clitic all interact in constituent negation \REF{ex:6:x1102}--\REF{ex:6:x1105}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Me} \textbf{napuma=ke} ifakim-o-k. | \gls not sickness kill-PA-3s | \glt  `It wasn't sickness that killed him.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: In clauses with \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{quantifiers}}, constituent negation has an important function disambiguating the meaning. If the subject or object noun phrase has a quantifier, the negation is done in different ways depending on whether the quantifier is in the scope of the negation or not. In \REF{ex:6:x1142} the noun phrase with the particular quantifier \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kuisow} `one' is not in the scope of the negation, but in \REF{ex:6:x1143} it is. The neutral focus clitic is required to clarify the meaning; it can even be attached to some other constituent between the quantifier and the negator \REF{ex:6:x1147}.
Content 1: \gll Mua \textbf{kuisow} \textbf{me} ekap-o-k. | \gls man one not come-PA-3s | \glt  `One (particular) man did not come.'
Content 2: \gll Mua \textbf{kuisow}=\textbf{ko} \textbf{me} ekap-o-k. | \gls man one=NF not come-PA-3s | \glt  `Not (even) one man came.'
Content 3: \gll Mua \textbf{kuisow} owowa=pa=\textbf{ko} \textbf{me} ik-ua. | \gls man one village=LOC=NF not be-PA.3s | \glt  `Not (even) one man stayed in the village.'

Knowledge Point: The example \REF{ex:6:x1145} is ambiguous as to whether only one man did not go down or whether it is negated that only one man went. The first alternative is the more likely meaning, and if one wants to make sure to give the second meaning, the standard strategy for constituent negation \REF{ex:6:x1144} is used.
Content 1: \gll Mua kuisow muuta \textbf{me} ekap-o-k. | \gls man one only not come-PA-3s | \glt  `Only one man did not come.' Or: `Not only one man came (but more).'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Me} mua kuisow (muuta) ekap-o-k. | \gls not man one (only) come-PA-3s | \glt  `Not only one man came.'

Knowledge Point: Similarly, with the universal quantifier \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{unowiya} `all', the scope of the negation may be ambiguous. The preferred interpretation for \REF{ex:6:x1148} is that the statement about not following God's talk refers to all people, thus \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{no one}} follows it; but it may also be understood that even if all the people do not follow it, some do.
Content 1: \gll Emeria mua \textbf{unowiya} Mua Maneka opora \textbf{me} ook-i-mik. | \gls woman man all Man Big talk not follow-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt  `All the people do not follow God's talk.'

Knowledge Point: If the negator is in the constituent negation position, the statement is unambiguous \REF{ex:6:x1149}. In this respect Mauwake behaves differently from Usan, which does not allow a constituent negation structure \citep[275--277]{Reesink1987}.
Content 1: \gll Nain \textbf{me} mua \textbf{unowiya} opora wiar op-i-mik. | \gls but not man all talk 3.DAT hold-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt  `But not all men/people believe in him (= some do).'

Knowledge Point: Stress may also be employed to give a constituent negation interpretation to a negated clause. When the clausal stress is on the negator, the whole clause is negated \REF{ex:6:x669}. In order to negate the universal quantifier rather than the verb, the main stress needs to be on the quantifier \REF{ex:6:x671}. This type of negation is used in Usan as well (ibid. 277).
Content 1: \gll Mua \textbf{unow=iya} \textbf{'me} \textbf{ikiw-e-mik.} | \gls man many=COM not go-PA-1/3p | \glt  `All the men didn't go (=none of them went).'
Content 2: \gll Mua \textbf{'unow=iya} \textbf{me} ikiw-e-mik. | \gls man many=COM not go-PA-1/3p | \glt  `All the men didn't go (=only some went).'

Knowledge Point: When a clause with the universal quantifier \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{unow onaiya} `all' is negated, it tends to be interpreted as a constituent negation of the quantifier, possibly because \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsxiiptItalic{unow onaiya} is a heavier structure than \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{unowiya} and as such more prominent \REF{ex:6:x668}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Unow} \textbf{onaiya} \textbf{me} ikiw-e-mik. | \gls many with not go-PA-1/3p | \glt  `Not all of them went (= only some went)'

Knowledge Point: The example \REF{ex:6:x1150} is not a case of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{unowa} negated separately inside a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}; instead, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{mua} `man' is fronted as a theme (\sectref{sec:9.1}):
Content 1: \gll Mua \textbf{me} \textbf{unowa} ekap-e-mik. | \gls man not many come-PA-1/3p | \glt  `There were not many men that came.' Or: `As for men, not many came.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Eliwa} `good' may be the only adjective that can be negated by itself inside a noun phrase. These structures are very rare and would need a more careful study \REF{ex:6:x1106}, \REF{ex:6:x1107}. \REF{ex:6:x1106} may also be a combination of a non-verbal clause and a transitive clause where the object \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} only retains the adjective; the noun is deleted because it occurs in the previous clause.
Content 1: \gll Maa en-owa \textbf{eliw(a)} \textbf{marew} p-or-o-mik. | \gls thing eat-NMZ good no(ne) BPX-descend-PA-1/3p | \glt  `They brought down not-good food.'
Content 2: \gll Biiris \textbf{me} \textbf{eliwa}, damo-damola=ko on-a-mik. | \gls bridge not good RDP-bad=NF make-PA-1/3p | \glt  `They did not make good bridges (but) bad ones.' (Or: The bridges were not good, they made bad ones.)
Content 3: \gll Maa en-owa \textbf{eliw(a)} \textbf{marew} p-or-o-mik. | \gls thing eat-NMZ good no(ne) BPX-descend-PA-1/3p | \glt  `They brought down not-good food.'

Knowledge Point: The example \REF{ex:6:x1114} looks like a constituent negation attached to the noun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{mokoka}\linebreak `eye(s)', but actually \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} here is a clausal negator negating the whole idiomatic sentence of `keeping one's eyes shut' (i.e. being ignorant).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Me} mokoka op-ar-ep ik-e. | \gls not eye(s) closed-CAUS-SS.SEQ be-IMP.2s | \glt  `Do not have your eyes closed.'

Knowledge Point: Those cases of constituent negation where \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} precedes a verb can be distinguished from clausal negation only in spoken language on the basis of extra stress on the verb \REF{ex:6:x1110}.
Content 1: \gll Ni iperuma fain \textbf{me} \textbf{e{\textprimstress}nim-eka}, wafur-eka! | \gls 2p.UNM eel this not eat-IMP.2p throw-IMP.2p | \glt  `Don't eat this eel, throw it away!'

Knowledge Point: A negative interjection is used as a one-word reply to a question or a statement. It stands as a complete sentence by itself or is preposed and syntactically independent of the rest of the sentence. Two of the negators are used as negative interjections: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{weetak} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wia} \REF{ex:6:x1115}, \REF{ex:6:x1116}. They are synonymous and usually interchangeable, but in a few environments one or the other is preferred. For the use of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{weetak/wia} as an answer to a negative question, see \sectref{sec:7.2.7}.
Content 1: \gll No aaya sesenar-e-n=i? -\textbf{Weetak/wia} (me sesenar-e-m). | \gls 2s.UNM sugar buy-PA-2s=QM -no (not buy-PA-1s) | \glt  `Did you buy sugar?' --`No (I didn't).'
Content 2: \gll Yomar owora efar aaw-o-k. -\textbf{Weetak/wia}, me os=ke aaw-o-k. | \gls 1s/p.cousin betelnut 1s.DAT take-PA-3s -no not 3s.FC=CF take-PA-3s | \glt  `My cousin took my betelnut. --No, it wasn't he who took it.'

Knowledge Point: When an affirmative clause is followed by a negative one, and the two only differ by the contrasted element, the whole clause apart from the contrasted element is replaced by \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{weetak} or \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wia} \REF{ex:6:x1119}, \REF{ex:6:x1120}. A full clause is possible instead of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{weetak}/\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wia}, but it is not as common.
Content 1: \gll Mua bug maala nain=ke mera unowa isak-i-non, mua bug iiwa nain \textbf{weetak/wia}. | \gls man wind long that1=CF fish many spear-Np-FU.3s man wind short that1 no. | \glt  `A man with long breath (=big lungs) will spear many fish, a man with short breath will not.'
Content 2: \gll Mera papako unowa, papako \textbf{weetak/wia}. | \gls fish some many some no | \glt  `Some fish there are many, some not.'

Knowledge Point: Also when an affirmative question is followed by a negative alternative, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{weetak} or \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wia} is used \REF{ex:6:x1121}, \REF{ex:6:x1122}.
Content 1: \gll Sira nain piipua-i-nan=i e \textbf{weetak}? | \gls habit that leave-Np-FU.2s=QM or no | \glt  `Will you stop that habit or not?'
Content 2: \gll Yo emeria=ko efar uruf-a-man=i e \textbf{weetak}? | \gls 1s.UNM woman=NF 1s.DAT see-PA-2p=QM or no | \glt  `Have you seen my wife or not?'

Knowledge Point: If an action fails to have the expected result, again one of the two negative interjections is used either by itself \REF{ex:6:x1124}, \REF{ex:6:x1126} or followed by a full clause \REF{ex:6:x1123}.
Content 1: \gll Marasin wu-om-a-mik=na \textbf{weetak}. | \gls medicine put-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p=TP no | \glt  `They put medicine in him but no (=with no result).'
Content 2: \gll Naap ik-ok uruf-am-ika-iwkin \textbf{wia}. | \gls thus be-SS see-SS.SIM-be-2/3p.DS no | \glt  `They were thus watching him (but) no (he did not revive).'
Content 3: \gll I unan maa en-e-mik en-e-mik \textbf{wia}, ipoka taan-ep enakiwa wu-a-mik. | \gls 1p.UNM yesterday food eat-PA-1/3p eat-PA-1/3p no stomach become.full-SS.SEQ half put-PA-1/3p | \glt  `Yesterday we ate and ate, (but) no (=we could not finish the food), our stomachs were full and we put half of it aside.'

Knowledge Point: When the clause expressing frustration of an effort starts a new sentence and begins with the additive connective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ne} `and/but', the negator is always \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wia}, and an explanatory clause follows \REF{ex:6:x1125}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ne} \textbf{wia}, papako=ke ma-e-mik, ``Weetak, moram owowa p-ikiw-i-yan?'' | \gls ADD no other=CF say-PA-1/3p no why village BPX-go-Np-FU.1p | \glt  `But no, others said, ``Why take him to the village?'' '

Knowledge Point: Mauwake has two different kinds of double negation. In both cases the negation is cancelled and the result is affirmative, but not an emphatic affirmative. A negated verb \REF{ex:6:x1131} or an inherently negative verb \REF{ex:6:x1132} may occur with the clausal negator \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} `not':
Content 1: \gll Ona muuka \textbf{me} sesek-owa=ke \textbf{me} ma-e-k. | \gls 3s.GEN son not send-NMZ=CF not say-PA-3s | \glt  `He did not say that he wouldn't send (lit: say about not sending) his son.'
Content 2: \gll Maamuma \textbf{me} \textbf{marew-ar-e-mik}. | \gls money not no(ne)-INCH-PA-1/3p | \glt  `We/They did not lack money.'

Knowledge Point: In the second type of double negation a speaker's negative statement is challenged by another speaker. In this case a different negator is used to challenge the original negation \REF{ex:6:x1133}.
Content 1: \gll Yo episowa weetak. -\textbf{Weetak} \textbf{wia}. | \gls 1s.UNM tobacco no. -no no | \glt  `I have no tobacco.' `Don't say you don't have any.'

Knowledge Point: The negation can be emphasized with the intensity adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{akena} `very' \REF{ex:6:x1134}, \REF{ex:6:x1135}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Weetak} \textbf{akena}, i me kuum-e-mik. | \gls no very 1p.UNM not burn-PA-1/3s | \glt  `\textstyleEmphasizedWords{{No}}, we did not burn it.'
Content 2: \gll I \textbf{me} kuum-e-mik \textbf{akena}. | \gls 1p.UNM not burn-PA-1/3p very | \glt  `We did \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{not}} burn it.'

Knowledge Point: Another possible strategy for emphasizing a negative statement or command is to attach the neutral focus clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ko} to the verbal negator \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} `not' \REF{ex:6:x1152}--\REF{ex:6:x1137}. In \REF{ex:6:x1136} the neutral focus clitic appears twice, as the speaker wants both to emphasise the negation and to distance himself from the situation (without implying that someone else did see what he did not).
Content 1: \gll I \textbf{me=ko} miim-a-mik. | \gls 1p.UNM not=NF hear-PA-1/3p | \glt  `We did \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{not}} hear it.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Me}\textbf{=ko} niir-e sa, kae napum-ar-e-k. | \gls not=NF laugh-IMP.2s INTJ grandfather sick-INCH-PA-3s | \glt  `Do \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{not}} laugh, grandfather is sick.'
Content 3: \gll Yo=ko \textbf{me=ko} uruf-a-m. | \gls 1s.UNM=NF not=NF see-PA-1s | \glt  `\textstyleEmphasizedWords{I} did \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{not}} see it.'

Knowledge Point: Negative spreading is fairly common in languages that have a medial verb system. The negation can spread forwards or backwards, or both, depending on the language. In Mauwake both forward \REF{ex:6:x1138} and backward \REF{ex:6:x1140} spreading is possible across medial clause boundaries, but only with the same-subject medial verbs.\footnote{In Usan, the negation of a final clause can spread backwards even with a different subject medial verb \citep[282]{Reesink1987}, but Hua, like Mauwake, requires a same subject medial verb \citep[408]{Haiman1980}.} The spreading is not common, but it is more acceptable if the verbs form a logical sequence, an ``expectancy chain''.
Content 1: \gll Nain yo \textbf{me} \textbf{ep-ap} \textbf{nefa} \textbf{aaw-e-m}. | \gls but 1s.UNM not come-SS.SEQ 2s.ACC get-PA-1s | \glt  `But I did not come and get you.'
Content 2: \gll Nainiw \textbf{ekap-ep} \textbf{maa} \textbf{me} \textbf{sesek-a-mik}. | \gls again come-SS.SEQ food not sell-PA-1/3p | \glt  `They did not come back and sell food again.'

Knowledge Point: But negative spreading is not automatic; even with a same-subject medial verb two clauses \textstyleParagraphChari{can} have different polarity \REF{ex:6:x1156}, \REF{ex:6:x1763}. If the speaker wants to avoid ambiguity, finite clauses can be used when the polarity is different \REF{ex:6:x1153}.
Content 1: \gll Nepa opaimika \textbf{me} \textbf{baliwep} \textbf{amis-ar-ep} wiena opaimik=iw yia maak-em-ik-e-mik. | \gls bird talk not well knowledge-INCH-SS.SEQ 3p.GEN talk=INST 1p.ACC tell-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt  `They did not know Tok Pisin well and talked to us in their own language.'
Content 2: \gll Mua lebuma \textbf{me} \textbf{arim-ep} takira ik-ok emeria wia aaw-i-mik. | \gls man lazy not grow-SS.SEQ young be-SS.SIM woman 3s.ACC take-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt  `Lazy men, not having grown and (still) being young, take wives.'
Content 3: \gll Nainiw ekap-e-mik, nain maa \textbf{me} sesek-a-mik. | \gls again come-PA-1/3p that1 food not sell-PA-1/3p | \glt  `They came back again, but did not sell any food.'

Knowledge Point: If the context is not clear enough, the negator can be repeated for each negated verb in a medial verb construction. In \REF{ex:6:x1139}, if only the first verb is negated, the sentence could mean that many people do not know the person but follow him nevertheless; whereas if only the second verb is negated, the sentence might be taken to mean that many people do know the person but do not follow him.
Content 1: \gll Mua unowa o \textbf{me} amis-ar-ep \textbf{me} ook-i-mik. | \gls man many 3s.UNM not knowledge-INCH-SS.SEQ not follow-Np-PR.3p | \glt  `Many people do not know him and do not follow him.'

Knowledge Point: Different-subject marking blocks negative spreading in both directions. Thus in \REF{ex:6:x1141} the polarity changes with each new clause:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Only the first and second person are inherently deictic, as they get their whole meaning, apart from the number, from the speech situation. The person marking is done by pronouns (\sectref{sec:3.5}) and by person/number suffixes on the verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.3.4}, \sectref{sec:3.8.3.5}). The special status of the first person as against both the second and third persons shows in the imperative and the switch-reference marking. In the imperative the dual number is only possible in the first person \REF{ex:6:x1262} (\sectref{sec:3.8.3.3.2}):
Content 1: \gll Aria, i owowa=ko urup-\textbf{u}. Auwa aite wia karu-i-yan, owowa=pa wia uruf-\textbf{u}. | \gls alright 1p.UNM village=NF ascend-IMP.1d 1s/p.father 1s/p.mother 3p.ACC visit-Np-FU.1p village=LOC 3p.ACC see-IMP.1d | \glt  `Alright, let's (dl) go up to the village. We'll visit father and mother, let's (dl) see them in the village.'

Knowledge Point: In the different-subject medial verbs the first person singular and plural share the same suffix, whereas the second and third persons are grouped together and the distinction is made according to number, between singular and plural \REF{ex:6:x1263} (\sectref{sec:3.8.3.5.2}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Even though the first and second person pronouns are already deictic in themselves, their unmarked plural forms can both co-occur with the proximate demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{fain} 'this', \REF{ex:6:x1269}
Content 1: \gll Ikoka Yaapan=ke ekap-emi \textbf{ni} emeria unowa \textbf{fain} nia aaw-urum-i-kuan. | \gls later Japan=CF come-SS.SIM 2p.UNM woman many this 2p.ACC take-DISTR/A-Np-FU.3p | \glt  `Later the Japanese will come and take all of you many women [here in this village].'

Knowledge Point: Locative deixis, which relates the location to the speech act participants, utilizes several different word classes. The proximate demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{fain} `this' \REF{ex:6:x1273} (\sectref{sec:3.6.2}) and the corresponding locative adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{fan} `here' \REF{ex:6:x1274} (\sectref{sec:3.6.3}) are truly deictic, as their meaning is based on the location of the speaker. The distal-1 demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} `that' and the adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nan} `there' are more neutral, and the less common distal-2 and -3 deictics have other defining features besides the distance to the speaker.
Content 1: \gll Ep-ap owora \textbf{fain} aaw-ep enim-eka, iwer(a) eka \textbf{fain} enim-eka. | \gls come-SS.SEQ betelnut this take-SS.SEQ eat-IMP.2p coconut water this eat-IMP.2p | \glt  `Come and take this betelnut and eat it, (and) drink this coconut water.'
Content 2: \gll Yo wia wiim-urup-ep \textbf{fan} wia wu-ap kiiriw iw-a-m. | \gls 1s.UNM 3p.ACC escort-ascend-SS.SEQ here 3p.ACC put-SS.SEQ again go-PA-1s | \glt  `I escorted them up here and went (back) again.'

Knowledge Point: In the location verbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{fan}- `arrive/be here' \REF{ex:6:x1275} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nan}- `arrive/be there' (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.3}) the deictic goal forms the verb root.
Content 1: \gll Auwa afura \textbf{fan-e-k} a, no=ko wiar akim-ap=ko uruf-e. | \gls 1s/p.father lime here-PA-3s INTJ 2s.UNM=NF 3.DAT try-SS.SEQ=NF see-IMP.2s | \glt  `Ah, father's lime is here, you try it and see.'

Knowledge Point: In the directional verbs \REF{ex:6:x1278} (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.5}) as well as the related bring-verbs \REF{ex:6:x1279} (\sectref{sec:3.8.2.4.2}) the verb root gives indication as to the direction of the movement. Only those directional verbs where the direction is clearly related to the speaker are deictic. The second person is not a possible alternative deictic centre for the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ekap}- `come'.
Content 1: \gll Uurika nefar \textbf{ikiw-i-nen}. | \gls tomorrow 2s.DAT go-Np-FU.1s | \glt  `Tomorrow I'll come to you.' (Lit: `{\dots}I'll go (from my present place) ...')
Content 2: \gll Mua imen-ap=na feeke wia \textbf{p-ekap-eka}. | \gls man find-SS.SEQ=TP here.CF 3p.ACC BPX-come-IMP.2p | \glt  `If you find the men, bring them here.'

Knowledge Point: Although the prototypical deictic centre is close proximity to the speaker, it may be extended to quite a large area. In \REF{ex:6:x1892} where the coming of the Japanese troops is described, it covers the whole North Coast of the New Guinea island:
Content 1: \gll Ne \textbf{ekap-ep} Numbia=pa nan urup-e-mik. | \gls ADD come-SS.SEQ Numbia=LOC there ascend-PA-1/3p | \glt  `And they came and landed at Numbia.'

Knowledge Point: In narratives it is more typical that the verbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ekap}- `come' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikiw}- `go', as well as the related verbs for `bring' and `take', get their deictic centre from the main character \REF{ex:6:x1277}, not the narrator, since the narrator often is not even a participant in the story.
Content 1: \gll Sawur emeria nain ikiw-eya o iikir-ami owowa ekap-o-k. | \gls spirit woman that go-2/3s.DS 3s.UNM get.up-SS.SIM village come-PA-3s | \glt  `When the spirit woman went (away), he came to the/his village.'

Knowledge Point: Temporal deixis relates time to the speech act, or alternatively to the time of a specific event. Tense marking (\sectref{sec:3.8.3.4}) is the most important device for this in Mauwake, as tense is an obligatory category in verbs.\footnote{In some Papuan languages tense markers and demonstratives are morphologically related (Cindi Farr, p.c.), but this is not the case in Mauwake.} The present tense marks the default deictic centre, the past tense refers to the time before that point, and the future tense to the time after it. The example (3.\ref{ex:3:x1029})
Content 1: \gll Unan \textbf{aakun-e-mik}, aakisa \textbf{aakun-i-mik} ne uurika nainiw \textbf{aakun-i-yen}. | \gls yesterday talk-PA-1/3p now/today talk-Np-PR.1/3p ADD tomorrow again talk-Np-FU.1p | \glt `Yesterday we talked, now/today we talk and tomorrow we'll talk again.'

Knowledge Point: is repeated here as \REF{ex:6:x1893}:
Content 1: \gll Unan \textbf{aakun-e-mik}, aakisa \textbf{aakun-i-mik} ne uurika nainiw \textbf{aakun-i-yen}. | \gls yesterday talk-PA-1/3p now/today talk-Np-PR.1/3p ADD tomorrow again talk-Np-FU.1p | \glt  `Yesterday we talked, now/today we talk and tomorrow we'll talk again.'

Knowledge Point: Papuan languages in general favour presenting a narrative in strictly chronological order, so a relative tense, where the deictic centre is shifted either to the past or to the future, is not utilized widely. This is true of Mauwake as well. When a shift to the past is needed, it can be done by right-dislocating a medial clause after a past-tense marked final clause \REF{ex:6:x1268}:
Content 1: \gll Wilkar wia muf-em-ik-om-a-mik, \textbf{mua} \textbf{kui-kuisow} \textbf{wia} \textbf{maak-iwkin}. | \gls cart 3p.ACC pull-SS.SIM-be-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p man RDP-one 3p.ACC tell-2/3p.DS | \glt  `They\textsubscript{1} pulled carts for them\textsubscript{2}, after they\textsubscript{2} had told the men\textsubscript{1} one by one.'

Knowledge Point: The same-subject sequential forms of the directional verbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ekap}- `come' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikiw}- `go' also have temporal deictic use, the former referring to time extending to the present moment, the latter mainly to time from the present moment onward. The examples (3.\ref{ex:3:x290}) and (3.\ref{ex:3:x437})
Content 1: \gll Naap on-am-ik-e-mik, \textbf{ekap-ep} aakisa. | \gls thus do-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p come-SS.SEQ now | \glt `We have been doing like that (all the time) up until now.'
Content 2: \gll No naap ik-ok \textbf{iki(w-e)p} mokoma enuma iiwawun aakun-i-nan. | \gls 2s.UNM thus be-SS go-SS.SEQ year new altogether talk-Np-FU.2s | \glt `You will be like that (long time) but next year you will talk.'

Knowledge Point: are repeated below as \REF{ex:6:x1941} and \REF{ex:6:x1942}.
Content 1: \gll Naap on-am-ik-e-mik, \textbf{ekap-ep} aakisa. | \gls thus do-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p come-SS.SEQ now | \glt  `We have been doing like that (all the time) up until now.'
Content 2: \gll No naap ik-ok \textbf{iki(w-e)p} mokoma enuma iiwawun aakun-i-nan. | \gls 2s.UNM thus be-SS go-SS.SEQ year new altogether talk-Np-FU.2s | \glt  `You will be like that (long time) but next year you will talk.'

Knowledge Point: The two groups of deictic temporal adverbs (\sectref{sec:3.9.1.2}) behave differently as to what the deictic centre is. The specific temporal adverbs, which refer to a certain day in relation to the utterance, always take the time of the speech act as their deictic centre \REF{ex:6:x1889}.
Content 1: \gll {\dots}i \textbf{uurika} ora-i-yan, ifera un-owa ora-i-yan. | \gls ...1p.UNM tomorrow descend-Np-FU.1p sea(water) fetch-NMZ descend-Np-FU.1p | \glt  `{\dots}we will go down tomorrow, we will go down to fetch sea water.'

Knowledge Point: The non-specific temporals normally do this too \REF{ex:6:x1890}:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: But their time reference may also be relative, with the time of the event taken as the deictic centre. This is especially true of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aakisa} `now', which is used for perspectivization.\footnote{The ``\textsc{was-now} paradox'' occurs in ``free indirect style'' when ``[t]he deictic centre of the utterance is the writer/narrator, but certain deictic elements are relativized to give the impression of direct access to the character's mental states: these include temporal and spatial expressions such as now, here, today {\dots} but not tense or person.'' \citep{MushinEtAl2000}.} In the following two examples, the temporal adverbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aakisa} `now' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aakisa fan} `just now', do not refer externally to the time close to the speech event; instead, they are text-internal perspectivization devices to highlight the importance of the event to the main characters in the text. \REF{ex:6:x475} is from an old traditional story and \REF{ex:6:x1891} tells about events that took place over four decades before the recording.
Content 1: \gll Nain or-op ``buu'' (na-e-k), \textbf{aakisa} eka saanar-\textbf{e}-k. | \gls that1 fall-SS.SEQ buu say-PA-3s now water dry-PA-3s | \glt  `It fell with a thud (and they knew that) now the water had dried up.'
Content 2: \gll Ekap-ep, ekap-ep, \textbf{aakisa} \textbf{fan} unowa Wewak=pa nan urup-\textbf{e}-mik. | \gls come-SS.SEQ come-SS.SEQ now here many Wewak=LOC there ascend-PA-1/3p | \glt  `They came and came, and just now many came up there in Wewak.'

Knowledge Point: Nouns are not inflected for number in Mauwake, and in the whole noun phrase the number may be left unspecified \REF{ex:6:x1284}. The verbs are marked for either singular or plural, but the plural form can be used also for unspecified number \REF{ex:6:x1285}. The pronouns must be either singular or plural. Besides these two obligatory number marking devices the language has several other means for quantification.
Content 1: \gll Waaya kiikir=iw uruf-i-mik, owowa=pa. | \gls pig first=INST see-Np-PR.1/3p village=LOC | \glt  `First they look at the pig(s) in the village.'
Content 2: \gll Nain pun sira naap=iw, mua=ko me kerer-e-mik. | \gls that1 too custom thus=INST man=NF not appear-PA-1/3p | \glt  `That was like that too, the (guilty) person/people did not appear.'

Knowledge Point: Numerals (\sectref{sec:3.4.1}) are used when the exact number is relevant \REF{ex:6:x1286}, \REF{ex:6:x1308}, non-numeral quantifiers (\sectref{sec:3.4.2}) are used elsewhere \REF{ex:6:x1287}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Masin} \textbf{erup} nainiw wu-owa epa ik-ua. | \gls engine two again put-NMZ place be-PA.3s | \glt  `There is a place for putting two more engines.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Waa} \textbf{muuka} \textbf{arow} ekap-o-k. | \gls pig son three come-PA-1s | \glt  `Three piglets came.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Emeria} \textbf{unow=iya} ikiw-ep eka nain imar-e-mik. | \gls woman many=COM go-SS.SEQ river that1 catch.fish-PA-1/3p | \glt  `All the women went and fished at the river.'

Knowledge Point: The third person plural unmarked pronoun functions as a pluraliser both in an ordinary non phrase \REF{ex:6:x1288} and with place names when the population of the place is referred to \REF{ex:6:x1289} (\sectref{sec:4.1.1}).
Content 1: \gll Nain \textbf{wi} \textbf{mua} sira=ke, emeria soop-owa sira. | \gls that1 3p.UNM man custom=CF woman bury-NMZ custom | \glt  `That is the men's custom, the custom of burying wife/wives.'
Content 2: \gll Irak-owa weeser-eya aria \textbf{wi} \textbf{Simbine} baurar-e-mik. | \gls fight-NMZ finish-2/3s.DS alright 3p.UNM Simbine flee-PA-1/3p | \glt  `When the fighting was finished, alright the Simbine people fled.'

Knowledge Point: Even without the pluralizing pronoun, the word for, or a name of, a village may occasionally, as a subject of a clause, refer to the population and thus be interpreted as plural. In \REF{ex:6:x1307} this shows in the plural marking in the verb.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Reduplication is another pluralizing device used in the noun phrase. Only a small group of nouns can undergo reduplication \REF{ex:6:x1290} (\sectref{sec:3.2.6.2}), but in adjectives it is somewhat more common \REF{ex:6:x1291} (\sectref{sec:3.3}).
Content 1: \gll Waaya pa-ep \textbf{kio-kiowa} naap uup-e-mik. | \gls pig butcher-SS.SEQ RDP-piece thus cook-PA-1/3p | \glt  `We butchered the pig and cooked the pieces like that.'
Content 2: \gll Owow(a) saria=ke kiikir perek-i-mik, \textbf{mua} \textbf{or-oram} fain weetak. | \gls village headman=CF first pull.out-Np-PR.1/3p man RDP-insignificant this no | \glt  `The village headmen harvest it first, not common people like this/us.'

Knowledge Point: Comitative noun phrases (\sectref{sec:4.1.3}) are used to indicate duality \REF{ex:6:x1292}, \REF{ex:6:x1293} or plurality \REF{ex:6:x1294}, \REF{ex:6:x1295}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{(Yo/I)} \textbf{auwa} \textbf{ikos} fan ik-e-mik. | \gls 1s/1p.UNM 1s/p.father together.with here be-PA-1/3p | \glt  `I and my father are here.'
Content 2: \gll No ikoka \textbf{mua} \textbf{owawiya} irak-ep me efar kerer-e. | \gls 2s.UNM later man with fight-SS.SEQ not 1s.DAT appear-IMP.2s | \glt  `Later when you and your husband fight, don't come to me.'

Knowledge Point: Personal pronouns have to mark the number,\footnote{Except for third person dative pronoun, which is wiar for both singular and plural.} but in cases where the number is unknown or unspecified, the plural is used \REF{ex:6:x1309}.
Content 1: \gll Ikiw-ep mua \textbf{wia} uruf-a-k na weetak, mua=ko me \textbf{wia} furew-a-k. | \gls go-SS.SEQ man 3p.ACC see-PA-3s but no man=NF not 3p.ACC sense-PA-3s | \glt  `She went and looked for anyone/people but no, she did not sense (there was) anyone (there).'

Knowledge Point: The person/number suffix in the finite verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.3.4}) is the most frequently used device to indicate quantification: it shows whether the subject is singular or plural. Often the person/number suffix in the verb is the only element in a clause overtly showing number \REF{ex:6:x1296}.
Content 1: \gll Mauw-am-ik-ok ik-ok mauw-owa weeser-eya urera ekap-e-\textbf{mik}. | \gls work-SS.SIM-be-SS be-SS work-NMZ finish-2/3s.DS afternoon come-PA-1/3p | \glt  `They came and landed there at Numbia.'

Knowledge Point: But if the subject noun is [-human], even the person/number suffix may not indicate the number, since plural marking is only used for humans and occasionally for large animals, and only very rarely for inanimates. In \REF{ex:6:x1283}, the verbs in both sentences refer to airplanes, but because the action in the first sentence is attributed to the soldiers inside the planes, the finite verb is in plural form.
Content 1: \gll Amerika irak-ow(a) iinan aasa ekap-ep Ulingan nan bom \textbf{fu-fuurk-ikiw-e-mik}. Iinan=iw iinan=iw wu-ami feenap Wewak kame naap \textbf{ikiw-o-k}. | \gls America fight-NMZ sky canoe come-SS.SEQ Ulingan there bomb RDP-drop-go-PA-1/3p sky=INST sky=INST put-SS.SIM like.this Wewak side thus go-PA-3s | \glt  `American fighter planes came and went on dropping bombs there in Ulingan. They were really high up and went like this to Wewak.'

Knowledge Point: Reduplication is more common in verbs than in nouns or adjectives (\sectref{sec:3.8.2.4.1}). In transitive verbs the reduplication indicates plurality of the resulting object \REF{ex:6:x1298}, \REF{ex:6:x1297}.
Content 1: \gll Kau nain pa-ep, gele-gelemuti-tik \textbf{pu-puuk}\textbf{-}\textbf{ap} uup-e-mik. | \gls cow that1 butcher-SS.SEQ RDP-small-RDP RDP-cut-SS.SEQ cook-PA-1/3 | \glt  `They butchered the cow and cut it into small pieces and cooked it/them.'
Content 2: \gll Aruf-irapar-emi meren(a) suuw-owa wiar \textbf{pere-perek-a-mik.} | \gls hit-to.and.fro-SS.SIM leg pull-NMZ 3.DAT RDP-tear-PA-1/3p | \glt  `They hit him all over and tore his trousers to pieces.'

Knowledge Point: Both the distributive suffixes (\sectref{sec:3.8.2.3.2}) mark plurality; the argument that the marking pluralizes depends on the type of verb \REF{ex:6:x1300}--\REF{ex:6:x1302}.
Content 1: \gll Iinan aasa fan \textbf{or-om-ik-omak-i-ya}. | \gls sky canoe here descend-SS.SIM-be-DISTR/PL-Np-PR.3s | \glt  `Many planes are descending here.'
Content 2: \gll O iiriw maa bala wiar \textbf{aaw-urum-ep} ona mia=pa-r=iw wu-a-k. | \gls 3s.UNM earlier thing ornament 3.ACC get-DISTR/A-SS.SEQ 3s.GEN body=LOC-{\O}=LIM put-PA-3s | \glt  `Earlier he had received ornaments from all of them and (now) he put them on his own body only.'

Knowledge Point: In the object cross-referencing verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.2.4}) the root shows singularity \REF{ex:6:x1304} or plurality \REF{ex:6:x1303} of the object that is cross-referenced.
Content 1: \gll Maa eneka kes mane-maneka oram \textbf{iw-e-mik}. | \gls thing tooth case RDP-big just give.him-PA-1/3p | \glt  `They gave him big meat (tin) cases for free.'
Content 2: \gll Iperowa opora \textbf{wiok-i-yan}. | \gls middle.aged talk follow.them-Np-FU.1p | \glt  `We'll follow/obey the talk of the middle-aged men.'

Knowledge Point: When a numeral follows a nominalized verb form and precedes the resultative verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ar}- `become' (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.4}), that indicates how many times an action was performed \REF{ex:6:x1305}, \REF{ex:6:x1306}.
Content 1: \gll Ewar maneka \textbf{muf-owa} \textbf{erup} \textbf{ar-e}. | \gls wind big pull-NMZ two become-IMP.2s | \glt  `Breathe deeply twice.'
Content 2: \gll Kiikir iinan=pa \textbf{akim-owa} \textbf{arow} \textbf{ar-e-mik}. | \gls first top=LOC try-NMZ three become-PA-1/3p | \glt  `First they tried it three times on top.'

Knowledge Point: One way to express comparison is to conjoin two structurally similar clauses, where the adjective in the first one functioning as the non-verbal predicate is not intensified, but in the second clause it has an intensifier. The first clause contains the standard of comparison \REF{ex:6:x1336}.
Content 1: \gll Poka fain \textbf{maala}, ne oko \textbf{maala} \textbf{akena}. | \gls stilt this long ADD other long very | \glt  `This stilt is long but the other one is longer (lit: very long).'

Knowledge Point: Although the clauses usually are descriptive, as above, they do not have to be. In the following example the locative noun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iinan} `top', functioning like an adjective here, modifies the head noun in both the clauses \REF{ex:6:x1324}.
Content 1: \gll Ema \textbf{iinan} urup-e-m, ne no ema \textbf{iinan} \textbf{akena} urup-o-n. | \gls mountain top ascend-PA-1s ADD 2s.UNM mountain top very ascend-PA-2s | \glt  `I climbed a high mountain, but you climbed a higher (lit: very high) mountain.'

Knowledge Point: Another way is to use adjectives that are antonymous \REF{ex:6:x1325}. As a comparative structure this is problematic in that it is arbitrary to call the subject of one clause the standard and the subject of the other the object of comparison.
Content 1: \gll Waaya nain \textbf{gelemuta}, oko nain \textbf{maneka}. | \gls pig that1 small other that1 big | \glt  `That pig is smaller than the other one.' Or: `That other pig is bigger than that one.' (Lit: That pig is small, the other one is big.)'

Knowledge Point: The same caveat applies to the following structure, where the adjective is negated for comparison \REF{ex:6:x1326}:
Content 1: \gll Auwa uuw-owa \textbf{eliwa}, mua oko fain \textbf{wia}. | \gls 1s/p.father work-NMZ good man other this no | \glt  `My father's work is better than this other man's. (Lit: My father's work is good, this other man's is not.) '

Knowledge Point: According to \citet{Stassen2008} this \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Conjoined Comparative}} strategy, exemplified\linebreak above, is prevalent in Australia and New Guinea. But the sample of New Guinean languages used for the generalization is very small (and includes both Austronesian and Papuan languages), and I suggest that at least for \textstyleAcronymallcaps{tng} languages the \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Exceed Comparative}}, the strategy represented in that sample only by Amele \citep[134--135]{Roberts1987}, is a possible alternative and may actually be as common as, or more common than, the Conjoined Comparative strategy.\footnote{My opinion is mainly based on the experience of working with national translators. When searching for translation equivalents for comparison forms, they often start with the Conjoined Comparative pattern, but very soon after realising that they do not have to stay within the limits of stative clauses only or stick to the adjective class, many actually tend to prefer the Exceed Comparative as the more natural and accurate expression for comparison. \citet[68]{Reesink1987} mentions both of these mechanisms for Usan. } There are two clauses in this pattern too: one may be equative and contain an adjective, the other is a transitive clause containing the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nomak}- `exceed/surpass' as the predicate and the standard of comparison as the object \REF{ex:6:x1327}--\REF{ex:6:x1333}. The order of the two clauses is free.
Content 1: \gll Maa mane-maneka, maa fain \textbf{nomak-ep} ik-ua. | \gls thing RDP-big thing this surpass-SS.SEQ be-PA.3s | \glt  `They are big things, greater than these.'
Content 2: \gll Nomokowa kakawa fain iiwa, oko \textbf{nomak-ep} puuk-a-m. | \gls tree strip this short other surpass-SS.SEQ cut-PA-1s. | \glt  `This piece of timber is short, I cut the other one longer.'

Knowledge Point: A transitive clause with \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nomak}- is also used, when a noun rather than an adjective describes the characteristic under comparison \REF{ex:6:x1329}, \REF{ex:6:x1894}.
Content 1: \gll O kekan-owa=ke yo kekan-owa efar \textbf{nomak-e-k}. | \gls 3s.UNM be.strong-NMZ=CF 1s.UNM be.strong-NMZ 1s.DAT surpass-PA-3s | \glt  `He is stronger than I. (Lit: His strength surpasses my strength.)'
Content 2: \gll Mua oko=ke ikiwosa/amisa efar \textbf{nomak-e-k}. | \gls man other=CF head/knowledge 1s.DAT surpass-PA-3s | \glt  `Someone else is more intelligent than I. (Lit: {\dots}surpasses my head/knowledge.)'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:6:x1895}, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nomak}- is employed to compare arrival times:
Content 1: \gll ...wia \textbf{nomak-ep} me miim-ep ... urup-i-yen, weetak. | \gls 3p.ACC surpass-SS.SEQ not precede-SS.SEQ ... ascend-Np-FU.1p no | \glt  `{\dots} we'll not go up earlier than they, no.'

Knowledge Point: For superlatives, the quantifier \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{unowiya} `all' may be used in the object \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} \REF{ex:6:x1330}.
Content 1: \gll No unuma nain mua \textbf{unow=iya} wia \textbf{nomakek}. | \gls 2s.UNM name that1 man many=COM 3p.ACC surpass-PA-3s | \glt  `You are the most important of all people.' (Lit: `Your name surpasses all people.')

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:6:x1337}, the two comparison strategies are employed in the same sentence, and the intensifier \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{akena} `very' indicates superlative:
Content 1: \gll Poka fain \textbf{maala}, nain \textbf{nomak-e-k}, ne oko nain \textbf{maala} \textbf{akena}. | \gls stilt this long that1 surpass-PA-3s ADD other that1 long very | \glt  `This stilt is longer than that one, and/but that other one is the longest.'

Knowledge Point: When there is a difference between things that are compared, but the difference is not graded, the phrase \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{sira oko} 'different (lit: another kind)' is used to modify the noun \REF{ex:6:x1334}, \REF{ex:6:x1335}.
Content 1: \gll Iwakara \textbf{sira} \textbf{oko} miim-ap baurar-e-mik. | \gls neck kind other hear-SS.SEQ flee-PA-1/3p | \glt  `They heard a different voice and ran away.'
Content 2: \gll Takira opor(a) \textbf{sira} \textbf{oko}=ko me wia maak-e. | \gls youngster talk kind other=NF not 3p.ACC tell-IMP.2s | \glt  `Don't tell different things to the youngsters (from what you are supposed to tell them).'

Knowledge Point: For an equivalent of `as \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{adj}} as' structure, the intensity adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pepek} 'enough' is used, often together with another intensifier \REF{ex:6:x1331}, \REF{ex:6:x1332}.
Content 1: \gll No merena \textbf{maneka} yo merena \textbf{iiwawun} \textbf{pepek}. | \gls 2s.UNM foot big 1s.UNM foot altogether enough | \glt  `Your feet are big, just as big as my feet.' Or: `Your big feet are just as big as mine.'
Content 2: \gll Urauwa maala Moro owowa \textbf{maala} \textbf{pepek} \textbf{akena}. | \gls hole long Moro village long enough very | \glt  `The hole (is) as deep as Moro village is long.'

Knowledge Point: The two most common words used in equative constructions are the deictic manner adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naap} `thus, like that' (\sectref{sec:3.9.1.3}) and the postposition \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{saarik} `like' (\sectref{sec:3.12.3}). \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Naap} is used to compare things that are essentially the same, even identical \REF{ex:6:x1338}--\REF{ex:6:x1348}.
Content 1: \gll Auwa mia maneka, muuka pun \textbf{naap}. | \gls 1s/p.father body big son also like.that | \glt  `The father is big, (and) the son is like that too.'
Content 2: \gll I maa en-owa \textbf{naap} nain yienak-e. | \gls 1p.UNM food eat-NMZ like.that that1 feed.us-IMP.2s | \glt  `Give us food like that.'

Knowledge Point: Also the corresponding proximal manner adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{feenap} 'like this' is used occasionally \REF{ex:6:x1347}:
Content 1: \gll Uura \textbf{feenap} nain, wi wilkar nain muf-e-mik. | \gls night like.this that1 3p.UNM cart that1 pull-PA-1/3p | \glt  `On nights like this they pulled the carts.'

Knowledge Point: The postposition \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{saarik} `like' expresses some similarity between two essentially different things. The actual point of similarity may be expressed explicitly \REF{ex:6:x1341} or left implied \REF{ex:6:x1340}.
Content 1: \gll Pon oposia eliwa, aara oposia \textbf{saarik}. | \gls turtle meat good chicken meat like | \glt  `Turtle meat is good, like chicken meat.'
Content 2: \gll Mera iperuma ifa \textbf{saarik}. | \gls fish eel snake like | \glt  `An eel is like a snake.'

Knowledge Point: The similarity may not be a particular quality, expressible with an adjective. In \REF{ex:6:x1342} it is the number of different things that is compared.
Content 1: \gll Ulingan fa=na iinan aasa nepa \textbf{saarik,} unow(a) akena. | \gls Ulingan INTJ=TP sky canoe bird like many very | \glt  `Ulingan -- wow -- the airplanes were like birds, there were lots of them.'

Knowledge Point: When \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{saarik} is postposed after a nominalized verb, it indicates pretension. This is a case of a similarity of action, but not ``the real thing'' \REF{ex:6:x1343}, \REF{ex:6:x1344}.
Content 1: \gll Moram era \textbf{paayar-owa} \textbf{saarik} fan yia p-or-o-n? | \gls why road understand-NMZ like here 1p.ACC BPX-descend-PA-2s | \glt  `Why did you bring us down here as if you knew the road?'
Content 2: \gll O Menamura \textbf{or-owa} \textbf{saarik} iwera fook-a-k. | \gls 3s.UNM Manam descend-NMZ like coconut split-PA-3s | \glt  `He split coconuts (for copra), as if he were going to Manam.'

Knowledge Point: In other cases it may not indicate pretension but a false or ungrounded expectation \REF{ex:6:x1345}:
Content 1: \gll Yo \textbf{efa} \textbf{sesenar-owa} \textbf{saarik} oram maneka uuw-owa yoowa on-a-m. | \gls 1s.UNM 1s.ACC buy-NMZ like for.nothing big work-NMZ hot do-PA-1s | \glt  `I worked hard for nothing, as if they would pay me for it (lit: buy me).'

Knowledge Point: The phrase \textstyleEmphasizedVernacularWords{nainiw akena} `exactly like' is reserved for the cases of striking similarity~\REF{ex:6:x1346}.
Content 1: \gll Wiipa nain onak miikapura \textbf{nainiw} \textbf{akena}. | \gls girl that1 3s/p.mother face again very | \glt  `The girl's face is exactly like her mother's.'
